query: What actions can be taken on Mediterranean farmland to increase crop yields?
relevant_summary:
- Use no tillage instead of reduced tillage: Replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain reported higher cereal yields with no tillage in some comparisons, while other Spain, Italy, Lebanon, and Australia studies found lower or similar yields depending on crop (cereals, fruits/vegetables, legumes, oilseeds) and comparison; legumes sometimes yielded higher with no tillage, while sunflower and some cereals/fruits/vegetables sometimes yielded lower (1358).
- Add slurry to the soil: Six replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found higher crop yields with added pig slurry in some comparisons; yields were similar between digested and untreated slurry, and varied with application rates in different studies (1349).
- Add compost to the soil: Replicated, controlled studies (including from Italy and Spain) found higher yields with compost in some or all comparisons, while other studies in Spain found similar yields; results can be inconsistent across sites and crops (1346).
- Plant flowers (flower strips): One replicated, controlled study from Spain found higher coriander yields next to planted flower strips than next to unplanted margins; one replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found higher tomato yields next to flower strips in some comparisons; yield responses varied with the number of flower species in margins (1360).
- Use organic fertilizer instead of inorganic: Replicated studies from Italy and Spain found higher yields with organic fertilizer in some comparisons; other replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and the USA found lower yields in some or all comparisons; studies from Greece and Spain reported similar yields between organic and inorganic fertilizer (1350).
- Add sewage sludge to the soil: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found higher barley yields with added sewage sludge; low application rates increased yields, while high rates did not differ from controls (1348).

Potassium (3 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Chile found more potassium in soils with seeded cover crops, compared to bare soils. pH (4 studies): Two studies (one replicated, randomized, and controlled, and one site comparison) from Spain and the USA found lower pH levels in soils with ground cover, compared to soils without ground cover. query: How do different organic amendments like compost, manure, and slurry compare in their effects on crop yields on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Replicated, controlled studies from Italy and Spain reported higher crop yields in plots with added compost in some or all comparisons, while other replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy and Spain reported inconsistent or similar yields [1346]. For manure, a replicated, randomized, controlled study from Greece found higher maize yields in two of three comparisons, while a replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found similar nectarine yields with or without added manure [1347]. Additionally, a synthesis of studies reported higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied, with evidence including studies from Spain and Turkey [911]. These documents did not report yield effects for slurry; slurry was mentioned only in nutrient loss comparisons [911].

query: What are the trade-offs associated with different tillage systems (no-till vs reduced-till) specifically concerning weed populations in Mediterranean arable fields?
relevant_summary: Across Mediterranean countries, reduced tillage often increases weed abundance: seven replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Lebanon, Spain, and Turkey reported more weeds under reduced tillage than under conventional tillage in some or all comparisons, though one of these also found fewer weeds in some cases, and one Italian study found similar weed numbers; studies from Spain and Turkey reported similar weed species richness between reduced and conventional tillage [1399]. For no-tillage, Mediterranean evidence from Italy and Spain shows more weeds in some comparisons and inconsistent differences in others, while a study from Lebanon found similar weed numbers; weed species richness was sometimes higher (one Italian study) but often similar (studies from Italy and Spain); additionally, no-tillage reduced parasitic broomrapes in an Italian study [1397]. These findings indicate that, in Mediterranean arable fields, both reduced tillage and no-tillage can increase weed abundance relative to conventional tillage in some contexts, with species richness typically similar but occasionally higher under no-tillage, and a potential benefit of fewer parasitic weeds under no-tillage [1399, 1397].

query: What is the evidence for the impacts of different grazing management strategies on invertebrate and mammal biodiversity in US grasslands within a Mediterranean climate?
relevant_summary: Across studies in US grasslands, grazing management shows mixed effects on invertebrates and mammals. Using grazers to manage vegetation: some studies found more invertebrates in grazed plots than ungrazed in some comparisons; simulated grazing reduced invertebrate numbers but not species counts; an endemic threatened butterfly did not recolonize after grazing was reintroduced; and invertebrate community composition differed between grazed and ungrazed plots. For mammals, abundances of some rodents were higher or increased more on grazed plots, while some species were less abundant or had lower monthly survival on grazed plots (1419). Under seasonal grazing, wet grasslands had more aquatic invertebrate species in continuously grazed plots than seasonally grazed plots in some comparisons (1421). Excluding grazers: in US wetlands and grasslands, some studies found more species or families of invertebrates in livestock exclosures, while others found fewer aquatic invertebrate species or no difference in abundance; a threatened endemic butterfly declined in both exclosed and grazed sites. In a wooded grassland, ground squirrel abundance did not differ between ungrazed and cattle-grazed plots (1417). Reducing grazing intensity: in wet grasslands, streams in areas grazed at lower intensity had more families of insects than those at higher intensity (1418).

query: What are the documented outcomes of restoring habitats along watercourses for different biodiversity groups on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Across available studies, all from the USA, restoring habitat along watercourses was associated with: similar bee visitation rates to native flowers between restored and remnant sites, but different plant–insect interactions; and similar numbers of bees and bee species but different bee communities in restored vs remnant sites (1408). One replicated site comparison reported more weeds in orchards adjacent to restored riparian habitats than those next to remnant habitats, with older restored sites associated with more weeds than younger restored sites (1402). Soil water amounts were similar between restored and remnant riparian habitats (1388).

query: How do adding manure, sewage sludge, or slurry to the soil compare in terms of their effect on crop yields on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: On Mediterranean farmland, adding sewage sludge increased barley yields in one replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain, with low application rates increasing yields but high rates not increasing them [1348]. Adding pig slurry increased crop yields in some comparisons across six replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain; two studies found similar yields between digested and untreated slurry, while one study reported lower yields with less slurry than more and another found similar yields across amounts [1349]. Adding manure increased maize yields in two of three comparisons in one replicated, randomized, controlled study from Greece, while another replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found similar nectarine yields with or without manure [1347].

query: What is the evidence for the impacts of restoring habitat along watercourses on different biodiversity groups on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: • A replicated site comparison in the USA found more weeds in orchards next to restored riparian habitats than next to remnant habitats, and more weeds next to older restored sites than younger restored sites [1402]. • A replicated, paired site comparison in the USA found bee visitation rates to native flowers did not differ between restored and remnant sites, but plant–insect interactions differed; the same study reported similar numbers of bees and bee species, but different bee communities, between restored and remnant sites [1408]. • Studies on providing riparian buffer strips in Europe reported mixed outcomes: three studies from the Netherlands and the UK reported positive influences on plant, invertebrate and bird diversity or abundance, and support for vegetation associated with water vole habitat; two replicated site comparisons from France and Ireland found no increase in the number of plant species with buffer strips; one replicated site comparison found ground beetle diversity was higher in grazed riparian zones and narrow fenced strips than in wide buffer strips, while assemblages in wide buffer strips were more distinct from adjacent pasture assemblages [120]. • A replicated, controlled study in the USA found that planting buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or the adult:tadpole ratio [819]. • A replicated study in the USA found grassed riparian buffer strips were used by up to five snake species [3586].

query: What are the most beneficial tillage practices for increasing soil organic matter in arable fields on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: A meta-analysis from multiple Mediterranean countries reported more soil organic matter under reduced tillage than conventional tillage (1371), and a meta-analysis from Mediterranean countries reported more organic matter under no tillage than with tillage (1369). Replicated studies from Italy, Spain, and Syria found more organic matter with reduced tillage in some or all comparisons, with two studies finding similar amounts compared to conventional tillage (1371). Replicated studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more organic matter with no tillage in some or all comparisons; one randomized study from Portugal found less under no tillage in some comparisons, one study from Spain found mixed results, and three studies from Italy and Spain found similar amounts with or without tillage (1369). Direct comparisons in Spain found more organic matter under no tillage than reduced tillage in some or all comparisons, while other studies found similar amounts; no studies found less organic matter under no tillage than reduced tillage (1370). Across broader evidence including Europe and Morocco, eight studies found maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure under reduced tillage, while one randomized, replicated trial from Spain found greater soil organic carbon under conventional tillage, and other studies reported higher soil organic carbon under no-tillage or reduced tillage than conventional (906).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity loss: Eleven studies from Canada, Europe, Mexico, or the USA measured effects of reduced tillage on soil animals or microbes. One replicated trial found increased numbers of soil animals and earthworms under reduced tillage. One controlled, replicated trial found mixed effects on microbe diversity depending on time of sampling. Two, (including one controlled, replicated trial) found no effect of reduced tillage on earthworm activity or microbe activity.
Compaction: Five studies from Australia, Canada, and Europe measured the effect of controlled traffic and reduced tillage on compacted soils. Of these, two (including one before-and-after trial and one replicated trial) found reduced compaction and subsequent effects (reduced water runoff, for example) under controlled traffic, and one also found that crop yields increased under no-tillage. Three replicated trials, including one site comparison study, found higher compaction under reduced tillage. 
Drought: Three replicated trials from Europe and India (one also randomized) found the size of soil cracks decreased, and ability of soil to absorb water and soil water content increased with conventional ploughing and sub-soiling. 
Erosion: Nine replicated trials from Brazil, Europe, India, Nigeria and the USA, and one review showed mixed results of tillage on soil erosion. Seven trials (one also controlled and randomized) showed reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage compared to conventional ploughing. One trial showed no differences between tillage systems, but demonstrated that across-slope cultivation reduced soil loss compared to up-and-downslope cultivation. Two trials showed that no-tillage increased soil loss in the absence of crop cover.
Soil organic carbon: Twelve studies from Australia, Canada, China, Europe, Japan and the USA compared the effect of no-tillage and conventionally tilled systems on soil organic carbon. All (including two randomized, five replicated, two randomized, replicated, and one controlled, randomized, replicated) found higher soil organic carbon in soils under a no-tillage or reduced tillage system compared to conventionally tilled soil. One review showed that no-tillage with cover cropping and manure application increases soil organic carbon. One randomized, replicated trial from Spain found greater soil organic carbon in conventionally tilled soil. One replicated trial from Canada found no effect of tillage on soil carbon.
Soil organic matter: Fifteen studies from Canada, China, Europe, Morocco, and the USA measured effects of reduced tillage on soil organic matter content and nutrient retention. Of these, eight studies (including four replicated (two also randomized), two site comparisons (one also replicated) and one controlled) found maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure under reduced tillage. Four trials (including two replicated and two site comparison studies) found higher nutrient retention under reduced tillage. One controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till compared to conventionally tilled soil, but conventionally tilled soil lost more carbon and nitrate. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial and one replicated trial found mixed effects of reduced tillage on soil nitrogen levels.
Yield: One replicated study from Canada found lower yields under minimum or no-tillage compared to conventional tillage, and one controlled, randomized, replicated study from the USA found higher yields when subsoiling was done. One randomized, replicated study from Portugal found no effect of tillage treatment on yield.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

A total of 42 individual studies (including seven replicated, controlled and randomized studies and six reviews) from Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Switzerland and the UK investigated the effects of reducing tillage on farmland wildlife. Thirty-four studies (of which 21 were replicated and controlled and seven also randomized, and five reviews) from nine European countries found some positive effects on earthworms, some invertebrates (other than earthworms), weeds or farmland birds, of reducing tillage compared to conventional management. Positive effects included increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms, greater abundance of some invertebrates other than earthworms, increased numbers of some weeds and/or weed species, higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying date and shorter foraging distances on reduced tillage fields, and greater abundance of some birds - including Eurasian skylark, seed-eating songbirds and gamebirds in late winter on non-inversion or conservation tillage. A review found tillage had negative effects on invertebrate numbers and no-till systems had more invertebrate bird food resources.
Twenty-six studies (of which 13 replicated and controlled and three also randomized, and five reviews) from nine European countries found reducing tillage had either negative, no effect or no consistent effects on abundance, biomass, or species richness of some invertebrates (other than earthworms), earthworm abundance, biomass, or species richness, number of different plant species found as seeds, number of some weed species, mammal abundance, some bird species, and one study found bird preferences for conservation tillage fields decreased over time. Two studies found that crop type affected the number of weeds under different tillage regimes.
One small replicated trial in the UK compared bird numbers under two different forms of reduced tillage, and found more birds from species that make up the ‘Farmland Bird Index’ on broadcast than non-inversion tillage fields.
Two studies looked at the long-term effects of reduced tillage on earthworms (after ten years). One study found higher earthworm biomass under reduced tillage, the other study found earthworm abundance was the same between conventional and reduced tillage plots.
Three of the studies mentioned above did not distinguish between the effects of reducing tillage and reduced pesticide and/or fertilizer inputs."

query: What are the documented trade-offs of growing cover crops in arable fields regarding crop yield and water availability in Mediterranean climates?
relevant_summary: Replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain reported mixed effects on water use: one found cover crops used more water than bare fallows, while another found no difference [1357]. Controlled studies, including from France, Israel, and Spain, found that plots with cover crops lost less water through drainage, runoff, or evaporation in some or all comparisons, though one replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found greater drainage losses with winter cover crops in some comparisons [1357]. For crop yields, six replicated, controlled studies (five randomized) from Spain and the USA found lower cash crop yields with winter cover crops in some comparisons; three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy and the USA found higher yields in some comparisons; seven controlled studies (six replicated, four randomized) from France, Israel, Spain, and the USA found no yield differences; and eight replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy and the USA reported inconsistent yield differences (sometimes higher, sometimes lower) [1351]. Implementation choices also mattered for yields: across studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA, legumes as winter cover crops produced higher cash crop yields than non-legumes [1351].

query: What actions can be taken to increase the number of natural enemies for pest regulation on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Plant hedgerows: A replicated, paired, site comparison found more natural enemies in fields with hedgerows than in fields with weedy edges and in hedgerows themselves compared to weedy edges, in some comparisons; it also found a higher proportion of pest eggs parasitized in tomato fields with hedgerows, but only up to 100 m into the crop [1401]. Add compost to the soil: Studies reported similar ratios of natural enemies to pests and similar percentages of pests consumed by natural enemies in plots with or without added compost; natural enemy numbers were not measured [1392]. Use organic fertilizer instead of inorganic: Natural enemy numbers were not studied [1393]. Exclude grazers: Natural enemy numbers were not studied [1403].

query: How does planting flowers compare to planting hedgerows for supporting pollinators on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Planting flowers: A replicated, controlled study from Spain found more pollinators on coriander flowers next to planted flower strips than next to unplanted field margins [1406, 2468]. Replicated studies from Spain and Italy reported that some planted flower species were more attractive to pollinators than others, and that planting more flower species sometimes increased pollinator numbers and sometimes decreased them; in Italy, bee numbers increased over time with three or six flower species but decreased with nine species [1406, 2468]. Planting hedgerows: Replicated, paired site comparisons from the USA found higher crop visitation rates by native bees, but not by honey bees or syrphid flies, next to planted hedgerows compared to unplanted edges; another study found no difference in bee visitation next to planted edges [1407, 2515]. Multiple replicated studies from the USA found more bee species (and in some cases more syrphid fly species or individuals) in fields with hedgerows or within hedgerows than in fields or edges without hedgerows; one study found fewer ground-nesting bees in planted hedgerows than in unplanted edges [1407, 2515]. Implementation findings for hedgerows indicated more bee (and sometimes syrphid fly) species in older than younger hedgerows, and in old hedgerows more bee species on native than non-native plants [1407, 2515].
